segment.source: System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One
segment.target: System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One

segment.source: System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One
segment.target: System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One

segment.source: UWP apps and games running on Xbox One share resources with the system and other apps.
segment.target: UWP apps and games running on Xbox One share resources with the system and other apps.

segment.source: Therefore, UWP apps and games will have access to the following resources:
segment.target: Therefore, UWP apps and games will have access to the following resources:

segment.source: In this preview, the maximum memory available to an app running in the foreground is 1 GB.
segment.target: In this preview, the maximum memory available to an app running in the foreground is 1 GB.

segment.source: The maximum memory available to an app running in the background is 128 MB.
segment.target: The maximum memory available to an app running in the background is 128 MB.

segment.source: Apps that exceed these memory requirements will encounter memory allocation failures.
segment.target: Apps that exceed these memory requirements will encounter memory allocation failures.

segment.source: For more information about monitoring memory use, see the MemoryManager class reference.
segment.target: For more information about monitoring memory use, see the MemoryManager class reference.

segment.source: Note When running your application or game from the Visual Studio debugger, these memory constraints do not apply.
segment.target: Note When running your application or game from the Visual Studio debugger, these memory constraints do not apply.

segment.source: This limit is only applicable when not running in debugging mode.
segment.target: This limit is only applicable when not running in debugging mode.

segment.source: Share of 2-4 CPU cores depending on the number of apps and games running on the system.
segment.target: Share of 2-4 CPU cores depending on the number of apps and games running on the system.

segment.source: Share of 45% of the GPU depending on the number of apps and games running on the system.
segment.target: Share of 45% of the GPU depending on the number of apps and games running on the system.

segment.source: UWP on Xbox One supports DirectX 11 Feature Level 10.
segment.target: UWP on Xbox One supports DirectX 11 Feature Level 10.

segment.source: DirectX 12 is not supported at this time.
segment.target: DirectX 12 is not supported at this time.

segment.source: For application development, it's important to keep in mind that the resources available may be limited in comparison to a standard PC.
segment.target: For application development, it's important to keep in mind that the resources available may be limited in comparison to a standard PC.

segment.source: For games development, it’s important to keep in mind that Xbox One, like other games consoles, is a specialized piece of hardware that requires a specific hardware-based development kit to access its full potential.
segment.target: For games development, it’s important to keep in mind that Xbox One, like other games consoles, is a specialized piece of hardware that requires a specific hardware-based development kit to access its full potential.

segment.source: If you are working on a game that requires access to the maximum potential of the Xbox One hardware, you can register with the ID@Xbox program to get access to Xbox One development kits, which include DirectX 12 support.
segment.target: If you are working on a game that requires access to the maximum potential of the Xbox One hardware, you can register with the ID@Xbox program to get access to Xbox One development kits, which include DirectX 12 support.
